baseline_groups.claim_summary: Information about the gender wage gap (T1) increases demand for labor market policy (composite z-scored index).
baseline_groups.notes: The z_lmpolicy_index is the primary outcome: a z-scored average of five individual policy demand items. The baseline row 1 with outcome z_lmpolicy_index is the canonical result. Coef=0.062, p=0.014, n=3031. Note that spec_id=baseline is shared across all 6 baseline rows; this group uses only the row where outcome_var=z_lmpolicy_index.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Information about the gender wage gap (T1) increases support for specific labor market policies (individual policy items).
baseline_groups.notes: Five individual policy items are the components of z_lmpolicy_index. All share spec_id=baseline distinguished by outcome_var. AAanchor (p=0.001) and legislationanchor (p=0.001) are significant; quotaanchor (p=0.118), transparencyanchor (p=0.488), and childcare (p=0.939) are not. These are secondary baselines.

global_notes: All 6 baseline rows share spec_id=baseline (non-unique); they are distinguished by outcome_var. Rows 58-62 (robust/outcome/*) exactly duplicate the G2 baselines with identical coefficients and p-values. Rows 63-66 (z_mani_index, large, problem, govmore) test the manipulation check / first-stage effect, which is a different claim than policy demand. Row 70 (cluster by wave) has an implausibly small p-value (1.87e-08) from clustering on only 2 wave groups. Row 83 (placebo/republican) has coefficient ~2.65e-16 likely due to multicollinearity with democrat+indep+otherpol.
